The 2025 @lionsclubs Convention is underway this weekend in Sacramento. It is the world‚Äôs largest service organization spanning communities in my district from the South Bay all the way to the Central Coast. The organization has supported our youth, cared for the environment, assisted the visually impaired, and provided disaster relief when it is needed.

During the tenure of  Lions Governor Stan Weitzman, the Lion‚Äôs launched innovative initiatives including the reintroduction of the Lions Quest Program, the chartering of the East San Jose Brahman Jiu Jitsu Branch Club, the academic forum now underway at Andrew Hill, James Lick and Mt. Pleasant High Schools (part of the student-led ethnic studies movement), and the new Morgan Hill, expanded outreach to refugees and the new diversity of Latinx in the region.  

Today my staff member presented this wonderful organization with a state Senate certificate for all the Lions‚Äô work

Hundreds of May Day marchers in downtown San Jose tonight rallied for workers‚Äô rights and social justice.

Staff member Mario Lopez attended the rally in support of the May Day March.

On a bipartisan, unanimous vote this week, the California Senate Judiciary Committee  passed my SB 750. This bill is a first-of-its-kind housing finance solution  that could fast-track the construction of thousands of affordable homes needed throughout California without burdening taxpayers. With federal cuts to HUD and various housing programs, now more than ever, the state needs to use every tool it has to produce housing.
 
Senate Bill 750 now moves forward to the Senate Appropriations Committee.

This is not just another housing bill‚Äîit‚Äôs a structural reform to how we finance housing. SB 750 could be the key to unlocking hundreds of thousands of shovel-ready homes currently stuck in limbo.

The bill is called the California Housing Finance & Credit Act. It establishes a state-backed credit program administered by the California Housing Finance Agency. 

The goal of the program is to keep housing projects moving forward instead of being bogged down for years with high interest rates.

Today marks the 50th anniversary of the fall of Saigon and South Vietnam that is known as Black April.
 
Events to commemorate this period in history are being held all over the state of California including a bus trip I co-sponsored from San Jose to Sacramento. Please take a minute to read the captions under the photos to see where some of these events took place.
 
As many as 250,000 South Vietnamese soldiers, hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese civilians and nearly 60,000 American soldiers died during the Vietnamese War.
 
Today for the first-time the Vietnamese Heritage and Freedom Flag was flown across the street from the Capitol in Sacramento. It was a powerful message to future generations that the thousands who sacrificed their lives so they could have the opportunity of freedom will never be forgotten.
 
The County of Santa Clara, California has one of the largest Vietnamese-American populations outside of Vietnam. I have been honored to represent the Vietnamese-American community as a school board member, a San Jose City Councilmember, a Santa Clara County Supervisor and now as a state Senator.
 
I authored the resolution allowing the South Vietnamese flag to fly legally anywhere in San Jose and Santa Clara County. The South Vietnamese flag is recognized by the city of San Jose, the County of Santa Clara and the state of California as the official heritage flag of Vietnamese Americans in California.

The @mothersmilkbankca today held a news conference in @countyofsantaclara to announce I am joining the organization in authoring SR 20 declaring May as California Human Milk Donation Month.  This is in honor of the dedicated efforts of human-milk donors, milk banks, health care providers, and advocates who work tirelessly to ensure that all infants have access to life-sustaining breast milk.

I will present SR 20 on the Senate floor next week. 
 
Nonprofit milk banks serve these special needs, address disparities in access and education, and ensure there are safe processes for those donating and receiving donor breast milk. There are only two non-profit milk banks in California: Mothers‚Äô Milk Bank California in Santa Clara County and UC Health Milk Bank at UC San Diego. For information on how to get the milk or donate it go to: https://t.co/DR1pWjfuHF

Increased awareness of the importance of human milk donation can help all health systems better understand the communities that lack access and need improved access to these resources.

I am very sorry to hear of the passing of longtime San Jose resident Alcario ‚ÄúAl‚Äù Castellano.

He was invested in his community for decades, long before he and his wife Carmen won  a large lottery California Jackpot in 2001.

After the Jackpot win, the couple invested millions to support Latino arts, culture and education non-profits in our community that changed the lives of many residents in our County.
I was a @countyofsantaclara Supervisor at that time and saw what a big difference the Castellano family‚Äôs donations made for for our area. In the Silicon Valley, tech titans come and go without giving anything back to the community. Al Castellano was  a titan for the people in our community.

RIP Al.

The death of Pope Francis will leave a huge void because of his lifelong commitment to the poor and marginalized. 
He was a man of the people, even riding the subway as a Cardinal in Buenos Aires, and he never lost his great compassion and humanity as he rose through the ranks of the Catholic Church to become Pope. 

He also never lost his  legendary sense of humor that belied his seriousness of purpose. And he never avoided asking the tough questions to world leaders. 

He championed historically progressive stances  from immigrant rights to LGBTQ rights & climate change.

Pope Francis will be greatly missed.

Earth Day is this week ever reminding us of our obligation to protect the environment.  This year‚Äôs Earth Day theme is ‚ÄúOur Power, Our Planet,‚Äù calling upon each of us to unite behind renewable energy, and to triple the global generation of clean electricity by 2030.

#SaveMedicaid A large rally took place on the @countyofsantaclara Plaza today protesting the $880-billion dollar cut in funding proposed by the Trump Administration!

In California, the Medicaid program is known as Medi-Cal but the money comes from Washington. Nearly one-third of Californians rely on Medi-Cal for their healthcare coverage. In Santa Clara County one in four residents get their healthcare through Medi-Cal funding. 

The cuts would put lives at risk, lengthen wait times for patients & further strain Santa Clara County‚Äôs four public hospitals.

For the second time this year ‚Äì though now with proper public notice, after Assemblywoman Hadwick and I joined the ag community in calling for a new hearing in February‚Äì a committee of the state‚Äôs Fish and Game Commission on May 15th plans to discuss changing regulations on the take of coyotes. While this is an open discussion with no detailed plans, removing the ‚Äúnon-game mammal‚Äù status of coyotes could mean having to buy a tag, establishing seasons and setting bag limits, and having to seek a warden‚Äôs permission through a depredation permit to stop coyotes that are attacking livestock. 
 
There is no scientific basis for establishing limits the way the Fish and Game Commission does for deer, ducks or other animals that we are trying to protect from over-hunting. These predators are more than abundant in rural areas and even in California‚Äôs suburban neighborhoods. 
 
Recent years have seen a dramatic rise in the state protections for predators ‚Äì including bears and lions ‚Äì and new limits on the ability of everyone from full-time ranchers to families with backyard chickens to protect their animals. And that‚Äôs not even counting the spread of gray wolves, which enjoy the strictest legal protections even as they prey aggressively on cattle herds. Adding new protections for coyotes is the last thing rural communities need. 
 
I am very grateful for the county sheriffs from around the North State who have joined in one voice to oppose any changes, which will not keep their communities safer.

I am proud to author #SCR70, proclaiming this week as #CompostingAwarenessWeek in California. Composting is vital for reducing landfill waste, cutting greenhouse gas emissions, and building healthier soils. By turning organic waste into valuable compost, we support our climate goals, conserve water, and create green jobs. Let us celebrate the progress we have made and commit to making composting a part of every community. #SustainableCommunities #caleg

I am proud to author #SCR68, proclaiming this week as #TardiveDyskinesiaAwarenessWeek. Tardive Dyskinesia is a serious motor condition that can result from medications used to treat mental illnesses, often going undiagnosed and misunderstood. By raising awareness, we support those affected and work to reduce stigma, ensuring everyone receives the understanding and care they deserve. 

As Vice Chair of the California Rare Disease Caucus, I am committed to advocating for Californians living with rare diseases and promoting innovation in treatment. #TDAwareness #CAleg @neurocrine

RT @EytanWallace: Assemblymember @AsmMaggyKrell (D-Sacramento) and Sen. @ShannonGroveCA @shannongrove (R-Bakersfield) are putting politics aside to introduce new bill AB 379, also known as the "Survivor Support and Demand Reduction Act." If signed, it would do the following:

- Establish a fund collected from offenders to community-based organizations supporting victims of sex trafficking.
- Make it a crime to loiter with the intent to purchase sex.
- Ensure that the crime of purchasing a minor for sex applies in any case where the victim is under 18 (this is especially significant given last year's forced amendment's placed on Grove's SB 1414 bill to -- in most cases -- exclude cases involving 16 and 17-year-olds. This bill would change that to include all minors.

This bipartisan bill is a priority for Krell and Grove and is a subject both have been passionate about during their careers in public service.

Prior to her election to the Assembly, Krell led the California Department of Justice‚Äôs anti-trafficking efforts and prosecuted major sex trafficking cases.

Over the last two years, Grove has introduced and advanced new laws (SB 14 and SB 1414) that, among other things, increases penalties for people convicted of soliciting a minor 15 and younger for sex. 

Krell and Grove spoke to me this afternoon. Below are their messages in part:

Assemblymember @AsmMaggyKrell (D-Sacramento) and Sen. @ShannonGroveCA @shannongrove (R-Bakersfield) are putting politics aside to introduce new bill AB 379, also known as the "Survivor Support and Demand Reduction Act." If signed, it would do the following:

- Establish a fund collected from offenders to community-based organizations supporting victims of sex trafficking.
- Make it a crime to loiter with the intent to purchase sex.
- Ensure that the crime of purchasing a minor for sex applies in any case where the victim is under 18 (this is especially significant given last year's forced amendment's placed on Grove's SB 1414 bill to -- in most cases -- exclude cases involving 16 and 17-year-olds. This bill would change that to include all minors.

This bipartisan bill is a priority for Krell and Grove and is a subject both have been passionate about during their careers in public service.

Prior to her election to the Assembly, Krell led the California Department of Justice‚Äôs anti-trafficking efforts and prosecuted major sex trafficking cases.

Over the last two years, Grove has introduced and advanced new laws (SB 14 and SB 1414) that, among other things, increases penalties for people convicted of soliciting a minor 15 and younger for sex.

Today marks an incredible victory for California children. With the signing of my bill, SB 1414, we are reaffirming our commitment to safeguarding the most vulnerable among us‚Äîour children. SB 1414 (Grove) increases the penalty for soliciting or purchasing a child for sex from a misdemeanor to a felony, with a caveat that 16 and 17-year-olds must be proven victims of human trafficking. Criminals have been far ahead of us when it comes to child sex trafficking, we must have a strong approach to eradicate this brutal crime and ensure no child is reduced to a commodity.

The enactment of both of my bills, SB 14 last year and SB 1414 today, provides a significant step in the right direction to protect our children from both child sex traffickers and buyers. This is a crucial step, yet there is still work to be done. My pledge to champion protections for ALL children in California remains unwavering.

RT @EytanWallace: NOW: Actor and activist @Janefonda is at the CA State Capitol to urge support for the ‚ÄúMake Polluters Pay‚Äù bills SB 684 & AB 1243 by @SenatorMenjivar (D-San Fernando Valley) and Asm. Dawn Addis (D-Morrow Bay).

‚ÄúI know it‚Äôs not easy to go up against big oil, but we have to,‚Äù Fonda said.

Per the bill authors, the bill will do the following:

The bill identifies and assesses a fee on some fossil fuel companies based on their fossil fuel emissions since 1990.¬†
The Polluters Pay Climate Superfund Act will:
‚Ä¢Direct CalEPA to complete a climate cost study¬†to¬†quantify total damages to the state (through 2045), caused by past fossil fuel emissions.
‚Ä¢Direct CalEPA to identify responsible parties and assess compensatory fees on the largest fossil fuel polluters proportional to their fossil fuel emissions 1990 through 2024, to address damages quantified in the cost study.
‚Ä¢Fund California‚Äôs future. Fees collected will fund projects and programs to mitigate disaster related rate increases for Californians and remedy or prevent climate-related costs and harms. The bill prioritizes labor and job standards and dedicates at least 40% of the funds to benefit disadvantaged communities.

4 - High demand at lower elevations slowed refilling tanks at higher elevations.

Two of our bills passed Senate Judiciary Committee! 

SB 414 expands oversight of charter schools to prevent fraud, improve governance and transparency, and hold bad actors accountable by implementing recommendations from a number of recent reports.

SB 720 is a pedestrian safety measure that allows cities to opt in to utilize an automated traffic enforcement system for safety violations occurring at red lights. Thank you to @TheCityofSac @SacPolice @SacPoliceChief for providing lead support testimony on this bill today.

Happy to be working on both of these important issues with great partners in my local community, including the much appreciated bipartisan support of @saccounty‚Äôs other  Senator, @SenRogerNiello

RT @SenatorAshby: With a somber heart I joined @CASenateDems in Palisades, Santa Monica, Pasadena and Altadena for conversations and a tour led by some incredibly resilient local community leaders - including several California State Senators.

The first photo is of an Altadena middle school, with the charred remnants of a brand new student led vegetable garden right in the middle of a neighborhood designated as a food desert. Once a point of tremendous pride - now a stark reminder of the toll these devastating fires have taken on everyone - especially the littlest Californians. 

There is much work to do. 

I‚Äôm proud to author a bill that is part of the Senate Fire Response package. 

The bill seeks to:

- keep licensed impacted businesses open during the recovery.
- address predatory real estate practices.
- enforce against fraudulent contractors.
- provide small business relief from state requirements.
- implement lessons learned from previous emergency situations to improve communication between licensed businesses and oversight agencies.  
- streamline portions of rebuild processes for cost and time efficiencies.

*photos are all from Altadena.
